The typical response from Muslims in my local mosque to the Hebdo attacks was "Oooh it was wrong and bad. SO wrong and bad! ... But —" and it goes downhill from there. There's always a but. If you believe in the Hadith, there is no such thing as free speech, and certainly not with respect to insulting Muhammad. Non-Muslims are not exempt from this. There are Hadiths where Muhammad orders the assassination of poets who were writing satirical or otherwise offensive poems about him. I won't quote them here, because some Muslims assert (without proof) that these poets were actually inciting military action against the Muslims, but search for Abu Rafi' or Ka'b ibn Ashraf if you're interested. The Hadith that I will quote to prove my second paragraph is the following, from Abu Dawud 40/11, which Sunni Muslims will of course recognize as one of the six sahih books of Hadith. "A blind man had a slave-mother who used to abuse the Prophet and  disparage him. He forbade her but she did not stop. He rebuked her but  she did not give up her habit. One night she began to slander the  Prophet and abuse him. So he took a dagger, placed it on her belly,  pressed it, and killed her. A child who came between her legs was  smeared with the blood that was there. When the morning came, the  Prophet was informed about it. He assembled the people and said: I adjure by Allah the man who has done  this action and I adjure him by my right to him that he should stand  up. Jumping over the necks of the people and trembling the man stood up.   He sat before the Prophet and said: Messenger of Allah! I am her  master; she used to abuse you and disparage you. I forbade her, but she  did not stop, and I rebuked her, but she did not abandon her habit. I  have two sons like pearls from her, and she was my companion. Last night  she began to abuse and disparage you. So I took a dagger, put it on her  belly and pressed it till I killed her. Thereupon the Prophet said: Oh be witness, no retaliation is payable for her blood." Note that the last sentence means that the murderer got off scot free. Also note that the slave girl was killed without going through any court of law or right of appeal. This is in direct contradiction to what apologetist Muslims will claim about due process being necessary before any Shariah punishment is carried out. So there you have it: freedom of speech Islam style. To explicitly answer the question: Any Muslim who follows the Qur'an and Hadith properly does not believe anybody has the right to offend Muhammad, and further, that lethal recriminations against such people are not blameworthy. Thankfully, most Muslims nowadays recognize that this sort of behaviour is no longer acceptable in today's world, and there are many apologetist Muslims who are trying to remove such Hadith and verses of the Qur'an from consideration. We should promote and encourage such Muslims wherever we can.

No Muslim, can remain a Muslim, if he or she offends the person of the Prophet (PBUH). Non-Muslims need to understand what the person of the Prophet (PBUH) means to us. He is the Seal of the Prophethood, and for us, the perfect embodiment of humanity, and perfection of human qualities. For us, he holds a stature and position of respect higher than that of a mother or father, and undertook unsurmountable struggles filled with painful ordeals, that he could have well avoided, for the sake of humanity. In the biography of the Prophet (PBUH) Ibn-Kathir narrates that the tribe of the Prophet (PBUH) approached the uncle of the Prophet (PBUH) Abu Taleb, and offered him riches, abundances, position and the keys to the Kaaba, if the Prophet (PBUH) refused to propagate the message of Allah Almighty, to which he gave the following answer” “Abu Talib ibn Abd Al-Muttalib tried to solve the problem peacefully, and after they had left the house, he talked to Muhammad, The Messenger of Allah (SWT) about the matter, because Muhammad, The Messenger of Allah (SWT) was loving his guardian uncle Abu Talib ibn Abd Al-Muttalib very much. Addressing Abu Talib ibn Abd Al-Muttalib, Muhammad, The Messenger of Allah (SWT) remarked, 'Allah (SWT) has selected me to be His Messenger. He has given me a message so as to lift the people from degradation. He has given me a message for me to call the people to worship only One God. Allah has ordered me to prevent the people from idol-worship and oppression. I swear by Almighty Allah (SWT) that even if they put the sun in my right hand and the moon in my left, and in return, demand of me to quit the propagation of Islam and pursuance of my divine aim, I will never do what they want me to. I am determined to carry on my duty toward Allah (SWT) to the last moment of my life, even if it means losing my life. I am strongly determined to attain my goal.' The life of the Prophet (PBUH) also reveals immense sacrifices for the propogation of faith in the wake of extreme violence, hate, opposition and vengeance. Please refer to a story I am sharing here, on the magnanimity, forbearance, fortitude and forgiveness of the Prophet (PBUH) when he was incessantly stoned. heckled and harassed from the town of Taif, on an attempt to spread Islam Muhammad’s ﷺ journey to Taif Furthermore, the Prophet (PBUH) is also referred to as the “Sealed Nectar” - for us Muslims is the epitome of human qualities embodied in perfection, an ideal we attempt to reach each breathing minute; simplicity, honesty, honor, equity, justice, morality and charity. For us he is also the perfect father, son, husband and grandfather. He is not just a lawgiver, and his prophethood does not encompass a few edicts; his life itself to be emulated in the closest manner possible. So for us, the Word of Allah Almighty and the person of the Prophet (PBUH) are both sacrosanct, akin to giving respect to the Law and the lawgiver.
